Re ''Schumer Urges Power Plants Be Built'' (news article, July 30):

We do need to build more power plants, but even the new gas-fired units that many utility companies prefer produce sulfur and nitrogen oxides, and ozone and greenhouse gases. It is most important that we keep our existing plants operational. The nuclear plants in the Northeast provide large amounts of power while emitting no air pollutants, but many other plants need to be refurbished and relicensed.

For more than two decades the Northeast has been underinvesting in its electrical infrastructure. Electrical utilities were pressed to reduce construction to keep rates down, and communities fought any new facility. It is paradoxical that politicians are now complaining that we have failed to keep up with increasing demand.
KENNETH O. LINDQUIST Kingston, N.Y., Aug. 1, 2000
The writer is president of the Northeast Technology Corporation.
